message.en_US: Welcome!\. This room is dedicated to explaining the various features of \c[3]AlyBox\c[0].
It's a small library mod created by \c[3]Alyxia\c[0] that has some features useful for modders.
If you have questions, please talk to the other advisors around the room.
The other main feature of \c[3]AlyBox\c[0] is called \c[3]Logic Steps\c[0].
This allows for the conditional patching of json files.
For example, let's say a modder wants to use assets, such as custom enemies, from a different mod within their own mod.

Normally, this would require you to declare the other mod as an install dependency.\. Otherwise, the \c[1]game will crash\c[0] when trying to use assets from a different mod if the player does not have it installed.
However this forces the player to download the other mod.\. Ideally, we would have bonus crossover content between mods only become available if we detect the other mod is installed.
\c[3]Logic Steps\c[0] can detect if other mods are installed, and conditionally patch cross-mod content into your own mod as a result.\. If not installed, then the content won't be patched in.
This gives the player more freedom over their mod list, and adds bonus crossover content only if the other mod is detected.
My NPC colleagues here can give a demonstration of \c[3]logic steps\c[0] using the \c[3]Arcane Lab\c[0] and \c[3]Autumn's Genesis\c[0] mods.
Remember, all of us here are part of the \c[3]XPC\c[0] mods, and neither Arcane Lab or Autumn's Genesis are install dependencies for XPC.
So how do they work?\. These two NPCs, unlike me and everything else in this room, are \c[1]not\c[0] part of the \c[3]map file\c[0].
Instead, there are different possible versions of them stored in an external \c[3]patch file\c[0].
Each NPC has one version of themselves where they simply state that their respective mod is not installed.
They also have an alternate version where they demonstrate the ability to load and spawn assets from their respective mods.
The \c[3]patch file\c[0] uses \c[3]logic steps\c[0] to check what mods the player has installed, and therefore which version of the NPC to put into this room.
...and that's how you use \c[3]logic steps\c[0]!\. Did all of that make sense?
Another example is the door to the custom skill room located in the lobby not far from here.
Custom skills require Arcane Lab to be installed, but XPC does not have that mod as a required dependency.
To solve this, we use \c[3]logic steps\c[0] to patch a locked version of the door that displays a warning message if Arcane Lab is not installed.
But if Arcane Lab is indeed installed, we instead patch an unlocked version of the door that leads into the custom skill room.
AlyBox adds a variable called \c[3]player.entity.name\c[0].
This will always show the player's current character, and will update when the player changes characters too.
Your current value of \c[3]player.entity.name\c[0] is \c[2]\v[player.entity.name]\c[0].
Lea!
This is very useful for modders.\. It can be used for character-specific dialogue or showing portraits other than Lea depending on the player's character.
It can also be used to gate modded areas designed to be played as specific characters.
There are many uses for this outside of map files as well.
